{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3595716,"name":null,"username":"AutumnPlanet","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/autumnplanet/{size}/260647_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-18T20:06:23.888Z","cooked":"

Greetings, we are working on the chassis wiring of our robot, it looks like the attached image. We connected the spark cables from under the belly pen to the pdh
and extended the spark cables using wago, what would you suggest to change?

20250418_2145241920×1440 457 KB

20250418_2145591920×1440 454 KB

Note: We have not shortened our battery cables yet, I would appreciate it if you ignore it.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-18T20:06:23.888Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":205.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":499676,"topic_slug":"cabling-recommendations","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70504,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cabling-recommendations/499676/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3595938,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-19T01:08:14.848Z","cooked":"

Very clean routing. I particularly like the close placement of the breaker to the PDH and battery. Also the SparkMax on NEO mounts (is the CAD for those public?).

The wiring is definitely pretty good for an offseason robot/test robot, but here are some recommendations I would make for an in season robot that it might be a good idea to practice and teach people on the full robot.

  • Running wires under the frame close to the ground like that seems risky to me. They can snag on things, some games might have terrain, and it seems bad for transport. Maybe it would be better if there was some sort of removable protection beneath, or you can try the brainpan approach that some teams do, if you have a suitable robot cart.
  • You’re using some inline and some non-inline wagos. Either is fine, but it feels like you used the normal wagos in some places where inline would be cleaner. I would be more standardized and purposeful about what you choose where, rather than just using whatever you have on hand. When I looked the robot of 841 in 2024 (a local team that I think has good reliability practices), they used a lot of inline wagos.
  • I would find a way to attach your wago connectors to the frame so they are not floating. This can be hard but Wago sells some mounts (some with built in strain relief, you can buy from Digikey) or you can look for 3d printed mounts on CD.
  • I would strain relieve your connections better. The way we typically do this is by zip tie each side of every connection to the frame or an adhesive zip tie mount (with some slack).
  • One of the most common reliability issues I’ve experienced is with the NEO encoder cable connector. I notice you ziptied the encoder cables into bundles. This is nice, but it doesn’t look like that bundle is particularly well constrained, so as it shifts around it will put stress on the connection. I would ziptie the encoder cable something attached to the frame before it enters the bundle (maybe an adhesive ziptie mount on top or beside the spark max?). I would also make sure you hotglue the encoder connection before the robot sees the field (a hotglue gun powered by a drill battery can helpful here).
  • I notice one pair of wires (by your hands) has an extra pair of wago connectors and what looks like a non-wago splice. Why is that? If it’s because you cut the wire too short, you should cut a new wire. I would highly recommend on stocking up on high quality flexible wire and using exclusively that on your robot (I like bonded silicone). I also think it’s a very bad idea to have your wagos below the frame.
  • Which ports you chose on the PDH seems kind of haphazard. I would make sure there’s a system.
  • Use this RIO power connector instead of the default screw terminal: roboRIO Power Phoenix Push-in Spring Connector - AndyMark, Inc (also available from Digikey, lmk if you need the PN). Also, very small thing, but I would turn the RIO 180 degrees so the power connector is closer to ports on the PDH, just for cleanness.
  • I would backup your navx power over USB so that it doesn’t reboot if you brownout (mxp power drops out at 6.3V)

I know this is a lot but reliable wiring is all about attention to detail. It’s also an area where there are good returns to doing things well upfront.

Here is a recent post of mine where I make product recommendations:

Wire Management Electrical
Here would be my recommendations for wiring: First, the key to good wiring is prioritization and planning. I was really proud of my team’s wiring this year, and part of the reason it was so good is that we had high standards for it, devoted two build days and many other assorted hours to specifically wiring, set aside robot space for it, really planned it out carefully, and people not on the electrical team understood the importance of electrical work. You should plan out your wiring runs and m…

Here are the CheesyCare reliability recommendations:

Most Common Issues Seen on Robots This year Technical Discussion
Hey, my name is Joey and I am the mentor that runs the CheesyCare group for Team 254. Our mission at competitions is to go out and assist teams at the event and make sure every robot is playing at its best. Nobody likes having a robot that dies on the field, having mechanisms that aren’t working the way we had hoped, or generally just being unreliable. I’ve been there and it’s not fun (at least for me). In that spirit, here is a list of the most common things that our crew saw and helped teams w…

Edit: I missed you are in Turkey so parts might be harder/longer to source. Definitely important to stock up on all supplies you need before the season then (and the good thing is that electrical supplies don’t go bad). There’s also alternate vendors for a lot of the products I mentioned.

Running wires under the frame close to the ground like that seems risky to me

I would go a step further and say there isn’t a way to really do it safely. At some point you’re gonna be putting your robot on blocks to test stuff. Most teams nowadays put their robot on cross members on their carts.

You don’t want those wires being the point of contact for whatever is holding your robot up. Eventually the jacketing will be damaged, and you will have an electrical hazard, and have to replace it. Save yourself the trouble and just keep everything above. The zip ties can wrap around to the underside, but wires should stay protected

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-19T04:34:46.698Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":94.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":499676,"topic_slug":"cabling-recommendations","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cabling-recommendations/499676/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3596121,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-19T04:47:18.861Z","cooked":"

Yes, agreed. They already have a sunken belly pan, so everything on the top side it protected. They should not be running the wires on the underside, they’re very exposed. It’s not like they don’t have space on the top of the belly pan for the wires.

Also, those Spark Max placement on the motors seems to leave the input/output wires fairly exposed to being hit by another robot’s intake/arm. I would just put those on the belly pan too.

Hello, first of all I apologize for not writing for a long time, I had exams. This is the CAD we use to mount the Spark Maxs:

drive.google.com

Neo_Spark_Mount.stl

Google Drive file.

Since we don’t have in-line wagos and they are not easy to find in our city, we had to use non-line wagos, we are planning to replace these wagos with solder during the season.

We tried to use the input close to the Spark Max as much as we can on the pdh, but if it stays under the bellypen, we are thinking of doing the wiring over the bellypen from the beginning to solve the problems you mentioned.

Since we live in Turkey, unfortunately we have problems in the supply of some materials, we will look for alternatives to the materials you mentioned.

Thank you for your suggestions, we will take them into consideration.
